qas.question: What was the industry source that produced Seattle's first financial vigor?
What name was given to the street Yesler Way?
After Yesler Way fell into ill refute, what was the term generally used for this type of decline?
What events occurred in 1885-1886 due to racial disputes?
What percentage of the Seattle population was Asian in 1900?

context: The first such boom, covering the early years of the city, rode on the <a0_0>lumber<a0_0/> industry. (During this period the road now known as Yesler Way won the nickname "<a1_0>Skid Road<a1_0/>", supposedly after the timber skidding down the hill to Henry Yesler's sawmill. The later dereliction of the area may be a possible origin for the term which later entered the wider American lexicon as <a2_0>Skid Row<a2_0/>.) Like much of the American West, Seattle saw numerous conflicts between labor and management, as well as ethnic tensions that culminated in the <a3_0>anti-Chinese riots<a3_0/> of 1885–1886. This violence originated with unemployed whites who were determined to drive the Chinese from Seattle (anti-Chinese riots also occurred in Tacoma). In 1900, Asians were <a4_0>4.2%<a4_0/> of the population. Authorities declared martial law and federal troops arrived to put down the disorder.
